speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. Rome. An ante-chamber in OCTAVIUS CAESAR's house.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Enter AGRIPPA at one door, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS at another

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: What, are the brothers parted?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: They have dispatch'd with Pompey, he is gone;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To part from Rome; Caesar is sad; and Lepidus,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: With the green sickness.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: 'Tis a noble Lepidus.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: A very fine one: O, how he loves Caesar!

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Caesar? Why, he's the Jupiter of men.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Spake you of Caesar? How! the non-pareil!

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: O Antony! O thou Arabian bird!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Would you praise Caesar, say 'Caesar:' go no further.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: But he loves Caesar best; yet he loves Antony:

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Ho! hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: poets, cannot

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number, ho!

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Both he loves.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: They are his shards, and he their beetle.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Trumpets within

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: So;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Good fortune, worthy soldier; and farewell.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, MARK ANTONY, LEPIDUS, and OCTAVIA

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: No further, sir.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: You take from me a great part of myself;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Use me well in 't. Sister, prove such a wife

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest band

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Let not the piece of virtue, which is set

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Betwixt us as the cement of our love,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To keep it builded, be the ram to batter

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The fortress of it; for better might we

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Have loved without this mean, if on both parts

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: This be not cherish'd.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Make me not offended

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In your distrust.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: I have said.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You shall not find,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Though you be therein curious, the least cause

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For what you seem to fear: so, the gods keep you,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We will here part.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The elements be kind to thee, and make

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Thy spirits all of comfort! fare thee well.

speaker: OCTAVIA
text_entry: My noble brother!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The April 's in her eyes: it is love's spring,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And these the showers to bring it on. Be cheerful.

speaker: OCTAVIA
text_entry: Sir, look well to my husband's house; and--

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: What, Octavia?

speaker: OCTAVIA
text_entry: I'll tell you in your ear.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Her heart inform her tongue,--the swan's

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: down-feather,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That stands upon the swell at full of tide,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And neither way inclines.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside to AGRIPPA]  Will Caesar weep?

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  He has a cloud in 's face.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside to AGRIPPA]  He were the worse for that,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: were he a horse;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: So is he, being a man.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: [Aside to DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS]  Why, Enobarbus,

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: He cried almost to roaring; and he wept

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside to AGRIPPA]  That year, indeed, he was

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: troubled with a rheum;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: What willingly he did confound he wail'd,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Believe't, till I wept too.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: No, sweet Octavia,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: You shall hear from me still; the time shall not

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Out-go my thinking on you.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Come, sir, come;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Look, here I have you; thus I let you go,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And give you to the gods.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Adieu; be happy!

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: Let all the number of the stars give light

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: To thy fair way!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Farewell, fa rewell!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Kisses OCTAVIA

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Farewell!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Trumpets sound. Exeunt
